params.text:
Professional Writing

Formal and Informal:

Language in Action

• Formal Language
  • Informal Language
  • Contractions and Abbreviations
Professional Writing: Introduction

In this module, you'll explore the world of professional writing! We'll learn the difference between formal and informal language, and when to use each one effectively in your emails and written communication.

Here's what you'll cover:

1. Formal Language (Formal Speech): This is the kind of language you use in professional settings, like emails to colleagues, clients, or your boss. 

  2. Informal Language (Informal Speech): This is the kind of language you use with friends, family, or in everyday conversations. 

  3. Contractions and Abbreviations: Contractions are shortened forms of words (e.g., "don't" instead of "do not"). Abbreviations are shortened versions of phrases or titles (e.g., "Mr." instead of "Mister").
Formal Language: Key Characteristics

When writing professional emails, it's important to use formal language. This shows respect and professionalism to the recipient.

Here are some key characteristics of formal language to keep in mind:
Complete Sentences:

• Use full sentences with a subject and a verb to express your ideas clearly. Avoid sentence fragments or shortcuts like "thanks" on its own.
  • Example: "Thank you for your email." (Formal) vs. "Thanks!" (Informal)
Polite Tone:

• Maintain a courteous and respectful tone throughout your email. Use phrases like "please," "thank you," and "I apologize for any inconvenience."
  • Example: "Please let me know if you have any questions." (Formal) vs. "Whatcha think?" (Informal)
Professional Vocabulary:

• Choose words that sound professional and appropriate for the situation. Avoid slang, jargon (technical terms specific to a field), or overly casual language.
  • Example: "Please utilize the attached document..." (Formal) vs. "Use the file I sent..." (More natural but less formal)
Proper Grammar:

• Use correct grammar, spelling, and punctuation to ensure your email is clear and easy to understand. Proofread carefully before sending.
  • Example: "We are planning on meeting next week." (Correct) vs. "We planning to meet next week." (Incorrect)
Formal Salutations and Closings:

• Use greetings like "Dear Mr./Ms. Last Name" or "Dear [Recipient Title]," and closings like "Sincerely," "Respectfully," or "Best regards
  • Example: "Dear Ms. Smith," (Formal) vs. "Hey David," (Informal)
Formal Language: Email

params.textField:
Dear Ms. Lee,
*Thank* you for your recent order for marketing materials.
Your order *includes*:
•	500 brochures (English)
•	200 flyers (Spanish)
•	100 roll-up banners
We expect your order to be shipped within 5 business days. You will *receive* a tracking number via email once your shipment is on its way.

params.textField:
1.*Formal:*  I am writing to request a meeting to discuss the project update.
•*Informal:* Can we meet to chat about the project progress?
2.*Formal:* Please find the attached report for your reference.
•*Informal:* I attached the report for you to check out.
3.*Formal:* We apologize for any inconvenience this may cause.
•*Informal:* Sorry if this is a hassle!

4.*Formal:* Thank you for your confirmation and we look forward to working with you.
•*Informal:* Thanks for letting us know, and we're excited to get started!
5.*Formal:* I hope this email finds you well.
•*Informal:* How's it going? Just dropping you a line...

params.text: Part 1:
Part 2:
Informal Language: Key Characteristics

Informal emails are used with friends, family, or colleagues in close working relationships. They allow for a more relaxed and friendly tone compared to formal emails. 
Here are some key characteristics of informal language to keep in mind:
Short Sentences and Exclamations:

• You can use shorter sentences and even exclamations to express yourself in a casual way.
  • Example: "Great news! I got the job!" (Informal) vs. "I am pleased to inform you that I have been offered the position." (Formal)
Contractions and Abbreviations:

• Informal writing allows for contractions (like "don't" instead of "do not") and common abbreviations (like "FYI" for "For Your Information"). However, use them sparingly and only if the recipient understands them well.
  • Example: "See you tomorrow! Don't forget your gym clothes." (Informal) vs. "I look forward to seeing you tomorrow. Please remember to bring your athletic attire." (Formal)
Emojis (Optional):

• Emojis can be used cautiously in informal emails to add a touch of personality or emotion. However, be mindful of the recipient's culture and age, as they might not be appropriate in all situations.
  • Example: "Looking forward to it " (Informal) vs. "I am eager to participate." (Formal)
Informal Greetings and Closings:

• Informal emails allow for greetings like "Hi [Name]," "Hey everyone," or closings like "Talk soon," "Best," or "See ya!"
  • Example: "Hey Sarah," (Informal) vs. "Dear Ms. Jones," (Formal)
Casual Tone and Slang (Use with Caution):

• You can use a more casual and friendly tone in informal emails. However, avoid overly casual language, slang you're unsure of, or anything that might be perceived as unprofessional.
  • Example: "That movie was hilarious! " (Informal) vs. "I found the film to be quite amusing." (Formal)
Informal Language: Email

params.textField:
Subject: Re: Need those sales figures ASAP!
*Hey* David,
Just *checking* in - any chance you have those sales figures ready *yet*? We need them *by* tomorrow for the team meeting. No worries if they're not quite there, just let me *know*!
Thanks, 
Sarah

params.text: Informal Language - Listening & Quiz
Please listen to the following opinions about writing formality and answer the questions:

choices.question: Question 1 of 3: According to Ben, when is it okay to use informal language in emails?
answers:
Only with colleagues you know well. 

Always, even with new clients. 

Never, emails should always be formal.

choices.question: Question 2 of 3: Why does Tarik say formal language is important in his emails?
answers:
To avoid confusion about financial information. 

To make friends with his colleagues. 

To show his creativity in writing.

choices.question: Question 3 of 3: When does Jemima say it's appropriate to use informal language with other architects?
answers:
When discussing ideas for a new building design. 

When complaining about a project deadline. 

When emailing a client about changes to their project.

params.text: Ben:

params.audioNotSupported: Your browser does not support this audio

params.text: Tarik:

params.audioNotSupported: Your browser does not support this audio

params.text: Jemima:

params.audioNotSupported: Your browser does not support this audio

params.text: Dialogue Text:

Ben: I use formal language in emails with new clients or my boss. It shows respect and makes a good impression. But with colleagues I know well, informal emails are okay. We can use shortcuts and even emojis sometimes, which keeps things friendly.

Tarik: In finance, accuracy and professionalism are key. So, even with colleagues, I mostly use formal language in emails. It avoids misunderstandings about numbers or deadlines. For casual chats, I might use a more informal tone in person or on a messaging app.

Jemima: When working on a project with other architects, we can be a bit more informal in emails. It helps build a good working relationship. But if I'm emailing a client about their new building design, I always switch to formal language. It shows them we take their project seriously.
Contractions and Abbreviations: Key Characteristics
When writing, it’s important to consider contractions and abbreviations:
Contractions:

• Contractions are shortened forms of words that combine the apostrophe (') with omitted letters.
  • Example: "don't" (do not), "can't" (cannot), "they're" (they are)
Abbreviations:

• Abbreviations are shortened versions of phrases or titles.
  • Example: "FYI" (For Your Information), "ASAP" (As Soon as Possible), "Mr." (Mister)
Informal Communication:

• In formal emails, it's generally safer to avoid contractions and abbreviations altogether.
    Use the full words for a more professional tone.
Clarity:
• Contractions and abbreviations are generally more appropriate in informal emails with friends, family, or close colleagues.
• Don't overuse contractions and abbreviations. An email filled with them can appear unprofessional or even confusing.
When to Use Contractions and Abbreviations in Emails:
Formal Communication:

• Only use contractions and abbreviations that the recipient will easily understand.
    Avoid overly obscure ones or those specific to your field of work.
Moderation:
Contractions and Abbreviations: Sentences

params.textField:
*FYI*, the client requested a few minor changes to the proposal
We'll need to finalize the design by *EOD* tomorrow. 
Please let me know *ASAP* if you have any questions. 
*I've* attached the revised document for your review. 
*We're* looking forward to collaborating with you on this project! 
*Don't* hesitate to reach out if you need anything.

params.textField:
Hi David,
*Thanks* for confirming the meeting tomorrow at 2 pm to discuss the marketing campaign launch.
*FYI*, I've attached the latest draft of the brochure for your review. *Let* me know if you have any suggestions or changes before we print them.
We can also discuss the social media strategy during the meeting.
See *you* tomorrow!
Best, 
Sarah

params.text: Module Summary Quiz
Choose the BEST answer for each question to demonstrate your understanding of the key skills for concluding professional writing effectively.

choices.question: Question 1 of 5: What kind of tone is used in formal emails?
answers:
Polite, respectful, and avoids slang. 

Casual and friendly 

Short and to the point

choices.question: Question 2 of 5: Which of these sentences is most appropriate for a formal email?
answers:
"I'm writing to request a meeting..." 

"Hey there, what's up?" 

"Can we chat about the project update?"

choices.question: Question 3 of 5: Why is proper grammar important in formal emails?
answers:
It ensures the email is clear and easy to understand. 

It makes the email more creative. 

It shows you are a fast typer.

choices.question: Question 4 of 5: What kind of language can you use in informal emails with colleagues you know well?
answers:
Short sentences and even exclamations. 

Technical terms specific to your field. 

Third person pronouns like "he" or "she"

choices.question: Question 5 of 5: What is the main difference between formal and informal greetings in emails?
answers:
Informal greetings can be more casual and friendly. 

Formal greetings never use a name. 

There is no difference, greetings should always be professional.
